newsitem.title: GERMANY: IfW institute-Tight ECB policy will hurt economies.
newsitem.headline: IfW institute-Tight ECB policy will hurt economies.

text.p: Economic growth in countries joining European economic and monetary union will weaken substantially in the first year of the single currency, scheduled as 1999, Germany's IfW institute said on Thursday.

The institute, which is one of Germany's six leading economic research bodies, said the cause of the slowdown would be the restrictive monetary policy it expected the future European Central Bank to conduct.
The ECB is due to come into being in 1998 and will take over responsibility for European-wide monetary policy in 1999.
The IfW said EMU hopefuls would, in the run up to the 1999 EMU start date, fail to take the necessary steps to stem rising inflation, adding that this task would be left for the ECB to take on.
The ECB would have to work hard to establish a reputation for being stability-oriented, the IfW said, a factor which would add to the likely restrictive policy.
In western Europe, the institute forecast inflation rates of 1.9 percent in 1997, rising to 2.4 percent in 1998, and said that economic recovery would continue to pick up during this year and next.
Fiscal policy was likely to change from being restrictive to more economically neutral in character.
Combined, these factors would bring Europe's economies to normal or slightly above capacity levels, the institute said.
